titleproper.value:
Guide to the George Marion Papers
                    <num>ALBA.045</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Wendy Scheir, 2003

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-28T16:26-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
George Marion was a journalist, author, and activist born in St. Louis, Missouri in 1905. After moving to New York City and meeting Celia Greenspan, Marion joined the Communist Party. In 1936, Marion went to Spain to cover the Spanish Civil War for the 
                <title render="italic">Daily Worker</title>and the 
                <title render="italic">New Masses</title>. Greenspan went to Spain shortly after Marion to volunteer as a medical worker. After they returned to New York in late 1937, Marion worked as a journalist and freelance writer, writing primarily on the Spanish Civil War, the Soviet Union, the Cold War, and censorship issues in the mainstream American press. Marion died of a heart attack in New York City at 50.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<list>
                    <item>Americans in Spanish Skies, dispatch in 
                        <title render="italic">From Spanish Trenches</title>, ed. Marcel Acier (New York: Modern Age Books, 1937) (as James Hawthorne).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">From these honored dead ...</title>(as James Hawthorne with by David McKelvy White) (Imprint New York, Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, 1939(?).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">"Free Press"; Portrait of a Monopoly</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1946).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Bases & Empire, A Chart of American Expansion</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1948).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">The Communist Trial: An American Crossroads</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1949).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">All Quiet in the Kremlin</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1951).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Next Hundred Years; V.1</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1953).</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Stop the Press!</title>(New York: Fairplay Publishers, 1953).</item>
                    <item>Selections from George Marion and Celia Greenspan's correspondence in Spain were printed in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade newsletter, 
                        <title render="italic">The Volunteer</title>, VII:2, July 1985.</item>
                </list>

<emph render="bold">Series III: Writings.</emph>Consists of extensive research, notes, and chronologies (typescripts and 3 x 5 cards) by George Marion detailing the progress of the political situation in Spain from 1913 through 1938. There is a proposal and a rejection letter for a book called 
                <title render="italic">Defense of Madrid</title>. Also included are typescripts for articles and books on the SCW, including "Civilian at Guadalajara," 
                <title render="italic">The Yanks Were There</title>, and 
                <title render="italic">Thou Too, Madrid</title>.

corpname.value: Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Historical Commission.
